summary: The documents reference P.O. boxes in two distinct contexts. One involves a P.O. box in Coral Gables, Florida, linked to the identifier "GRACE HOLMES," mentioned in classified messages sent to multiple CIA stations in December 1963. The other involves a P.O. box in Washington, D.C., established in April 1972 under the alias "Diego S. Mardones" for Officer Gilbert Richmond. The Coral Gables P.O. box appears in the context of intelligence communications, while the Washington D.C. P.O. box is related to security measures and aliases within the CIA.
significance: The significance of the P.O. boxes lies in their potential use for covert communications and operations. The Coral Gables P.O. box, linked to "Grace Holmes," suggests a possible connection to intelligence activities or individuals of interest to the CIA in the context of the JFK assassination era. The Washington D.C. P.O. box illustrates the CIA's use of aliases and secure communication channels for its personnel.
